text: Today, we honor Chicago-native Gwendolyn Brooks. Brooks demonstrated compassion -- a ReGen virtue, in how she represented the struggles and triumphs of her community. Brooks was a poet, author, and teacher and the first African-American to receive a Pulitzer Prize.

NO READING REQUIRED! Join us on Wednesday, April 13th at 5:30 pm at Panama 66 in Balboa Park to discuss "The Misadventures of Awkward Black Girl" by Issa Rae. Describes as "A book ripe with insights" and "You'll laugh freakishly hard", it's sure to be a great book and discussion. We will have a Zoom option as well! For the Zoom link, please email bookclub@sandiegonaacp.org. #naacp #bookclub #naacpsandiego

On this day, in 1861, Confederate Vice President Alexander Stephens delivers his Cornerstone Speech, outlining what he believes are the reasons for what he termed was a "revolution." This revolution resulted in the American Civil War. Stephens's speech is remembered by many for its defense of slavery, its outlining of the perceived differences between the North and the South, and the racial rhetoric used to show the inferiority of African Americans stating, in part, "Our new government is founded upon exactly the opposite idea; its foundations are laid, its corner-stone rests, upon the great truth that the negro is not equal to the white man; that slavery subordination to the superior race is his natural and normal condition." A few weeks after the speech, on April 12, 1861, Confederate forces fired on Fort Sumter in Charleston Harbor, initiating the American Civil War. #naacp #naacpsandiego #naacpsdremembers

The freedom of African Americans from slavery in the U.S. in 1865 is celebrated on the holiday Juneteenth on June 19. Juneteenth is made up of the words ‚ÄòJune‚Äô and ‚Äònineteenth,‚Äô and it is on this day that Major General Gordon Granger arrived in Texas more than 155 years ago to inform slaves that slavery had been abolished. Allies, acknowledging this day and its history is a part of the work. #juneteenth

All participants are required to wear a mask and have their temperatures checked. Please do not attend if you are experiencing cold or flu-like symptoms or symptoms associated with Covid-19. For more information email Gayle McWilliams at agatheringplace2017@gmail.com or call 510-882-2286

May 7th at 11am, the Negro Leagues Baseball Museum Is encouraging the public to join them for the "March of the Monarchs" to give the 1942 World Series Champions the celebration they never received. It's an idea that stems from the tradition of a marching band leading Monarchs fans from 18th & Vine to 22nd & Brooklyn on Opening Day but this time, the route is reversed. We encourage you to swing by our Team Store located here at Legends Field to get your official Monarchs gear and wear it proudly that day. Store hours are M-F 10a-4p. Stadium Address: 1800 Village West Parkway KCKS

Public Health Week - Public Health is... Where you are. Racism harms us all. While people of color experience more direct negative consequences on their health and wellness due to racism, the inequity driven by racism affects society as a whole. A 2020 estimate found that closing racial gaps in income, wealth and education could add $5 trillion to the U.S. economy over the next five years. Ensuring schools are integrated by race and social economic status improves educational attainment for low-income students, and long-term racial relations and social cohesion for all students. Further, by naming and addressing racism and advancing racial equity, we can also address other areas of marginalization, including ability, gender, sexual orientation and age. We can combat climate change and other environmental health challenges, and their disproportionate impact on front-line communities and communities of colo

Ildaura Murillo-Rohde was a Panamanian nurse who broke barriers in establishing the National Association of Hispanic Nurses. As a non-profit founded and lead by women, NHMA reaffirms its dedication to carry forth the work of leaders like her in healthcare advocacy and diversity in medicine, especially in the light of #WomensHistoryMonth.

Norfolk Academy is closed today, Memorial Day, in honor of all the women and men who have given their lives in service to our nation. Last week, Middle School Math Teacher Nick Rahall delivered a Memorial Day Chapel, giving students time to reflect and prepare for a challenge that he issued as part of the holiday to commemorate those who gave their lives for our country. Mr. Rahall spoke about Lt. Michael Murphy, a Navy SEAL who lost his life while fighting heroically to save his comrades in Afghanistan in a surprise attack. The 2005 incident, for which Lt. Murphy was posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor, was the subject of the movie, "Lone Survivor." In addition, CrossFit gyms have created an extremely challenging workout, "Murph," in his honor; it consists of 100 pullups, 200 pushups, and 300 squats, framed by two 1-mile runs. Mr. Rahall - a U.S. Naval Academy graduate and officer in the Marine Corps for several years - has accomplished that workout, and he encouraged students to try it, or to try to do any difficult activity over the weekend to honor those who died for our country.
